linkedin_essay.text:
The idea that the world might divide into two incompatible technological civilisations sounds dramatic. It has happened before. More than once.

The deepest historical parallel is the millennium-long rivalry between Rome and Persia. From roughly 200 BC to AD 650, the Mediterranean world and the Iranian plateau developed sophisticated but largely separate technological ecosystems. Both empires built roads, aqueducts, administrative systems, and military technologies. Both were literate, urban, and commercially active. But they shared remarkably little. Roman concrete, arch construction, and urban planning had no Persian equivalents. Persian irrigation techniques, cavalry warfare, and administrative practices â€” the Sassanid postal system was the most efficient in the ancient world â€” had no Roman parallels. The two empires traded luxury goods across their shared frontier, but they did not trade technology or technical knowledge in any systematic way (Canepa, 2009).

The result was that for over eight centuries, two of the most advanced civilisations on Earth developed in parallel but in isolation. When Rome fell, Persian technology did not fill the gap in the West. When Persia fell to the Arab conquests, Roman technology did not rescue the East. Each collapse was absolute within its own ecosystem. The technologies of one civilisation were not portable to the other because the underlying standards, materials, training, and institutional knowledge were incompatible.
